description: The State shall not deny to any person equality before the law or the equal protection of the laws within the territory of India.
simple_explanation: Every person, Indian or foreigner, is treated equally before the law. No special privileges based on wealth, status, or background.
examples: If two people commit the same crime, they will face the same punishment, regardless of social status.
A government officer and a normal citizen are equally subject to the law.

article_title: Protection of certain rights regarding freedom of speech, etc.
description: All citizens shall have the right to freedom of speech and expression, to assemble peacefully, to form associations, to move freely, to reside and settle in any part of India, and to practice any profession or carry on any trade.
constitutional_principle: Fundamental Rights - Freedom of Speech and Expression
simple_explanation: Indians can speak freely, protest peacefully, form groups, travel across India, and work in any profession they choose.
examples: You can express your opinion on social media without government interference (within reasonable restrictions).
Citizens can move to any state for education or work.

article_title: Protection of life and personal liberty
description: No person shall be deprived of his life or personal liberty except according to procedure established by law.
simple_explanation: Every person has the right to live with dignity. The government cannot take away life or freedom without fair legal procedure.
examples: Right to privacy was declared part of Article 21 by the Supreme Court.
Police cannot arrest someone without following proper legal procedures.

description: The right to move the Supreme Court by appropriate proceedings for the enforcement of Fundamental Rights is guaranteed.
simple_explanation: If your fundamental rights are violated, you can directly approach the Supreme Court for justice.
examples: If freedom of speech is unfairly restricted, you can file a petition in the Supreme Court.
Dr. B.R. Ambedkar called Article 32 the 'heart and soul' of the Constitution.

article_title: Power of Parliament to amend the Constitution
description: Parliament may amend by way of addition, variation, or repeal any provision of this Constitution in accordance with the procedure laid down.
simple_explanation: Parliament has the power to change the Constitution, but it must follow a strict procedure and cannot alter the 'basic structure'.
examples: The 42nd Amendment (1976) is known as the 'Mini-Constitution'.
In Kesavananda Bharati case, the Supreme Court ruled that the 'basic structure' cannot be amended.

description: In this Part, unless the context otherwise requires, 'the State' includes the Government and Parliament of India, the Government and Legislature of each State, and all local or other authorities within the territory of India or under the control of the Government of India.
simple_explanation: When the Constitution says 'State', it includes the central government, state governments, and public authorities.
examples: A government company or authority like LIC is considered part of the 'State' under Article 12.
Fundamental rights can be enforced against government authorities.

description: The State shall not discriminate against any citizen on grounds only of religion, race, caste, sex, or place of birth.
simple_explanation: No one can be treated unfairly because of religion, caste, gender, race, or birthplace.
examples: A government job cannot deny someone only because of caste.
A university cannot exclude women from applying just because of their gender.

article_title: Equality of opportunity in public employment
description: There shall be equality of opportunity for all citizens in matters relating to employment or appointment to any office under the State.
simple_explanation: All citizens should get equal chances in government jobs. Reservations are allowed for backward classes.
examples: Recruitment exams must be open for all eligible candidates.
SC/ST and OBC reservations in government jobs are permitted.

description: Untouchability is abolished and its practice in any form is forbidden. The enforcement of any disability arising out of 'untouchability' shall be an offence punishable by law.
simple_explanation: No one can be treated as 'untouchable' in society. Any such practice is illegal.
examples: Preventing someone from entering a temple because of caste is a violation.
Untouchability Offences Act, 1955 was made to enforce this.

description: All citizens shall have the right to freedom of speech and expression, to assemble peacefully, to form associations, to move freely, to reside and settle in any part of India, and to practice any profession or carry on any occupation, trade or business.
simple_explanation: People can express opinions, protest peacefully, move anywhere, and choose jobs freely, within reasonable restrictions.
examples: You can criticize government policies in a peaceful protest.
Citizens can move to any state for work or education.

description: The State shall provide free and compulsory education to all children of the age of six to fourteen years in such manner as the State may, by law, determine.
simple_explanation: Every child between 6–14 years has a right to free education.
examples: Government schools must provide free education up to class 8.
Private schools must reserve some seats for children from weaker sections.

description: The right to move the Supreme Court by appropriate proceedings for the enforcement of Fundamental Rights is guaranteed.
simple_explanation: If your fundamental rights are violated, you can directly go to the Supreme Court.
examples: You can file a writ petition in the Supreme Court against unlawful detention.
Dr. Ambedkar called this the 'heart and soul' of the Constitution.

description: The State shall endeavour to secure for the citizens a uniform civil code throughout the territory of India.
constitutional_principle: Directive Principle - Equality in Personal Laws
simple_explanation: India should have a common set of personal laws (like marriage, divorce, inheritance) for all religions.
examples: Currently, Hindus, Muslims, and Christians follow different marriage laws.
The debate on UCC continues in modern politics.

description: It shall be the duty of every citizen of India to abide by the Constitution and respect its ideals and institutions, the National Flag and the National Anthem.
simple_explanation: Every citizen has duties like respecting the Constitution, environment, and promoting harmony.
examples: Respecting the National Anthem is a duty.
Protecting forests and wildlife is part of fundamental duties.

description: Parliament may amend by way of addition, variation, or repeal any provision of this Constitution in accordance with the procedure laid down.
simple_explanation: Parliament can change the Constitution but cannot alter its 'basic structure'.
examples: The 42nd Amendment (1976) made major changes to Fundamental Duties.
The Kesavananda Bharati case restricted Parliament from destroying the basic structure.

article_title: Protection in respect of conviction for offences
description: No person shall be convicted of any offence except for violation of law in force at the time of the commission of the act, and shall not be subjected to a penalty greater than that prescribed by law.
constitutional_principle: Protection against ex post facto laws, double jeopardy, and self-incrimination
simple_explanation: You cannot be punished under a law made after your act, cannot be punished twice for the same crime, and cannot be forced to testify against yourself.
examples: If something was legal yesterday, you cannot be punished today because a new law bans it.
One cannot be tried twice for the same offence.

article_title: Protection of life and personal liberty in cases of preventive detention
description: Provides rights in case of arrest and detention, but also permits preventive detention for reasons of state security and public order.
simple_explanation: Everyone has rights if arrested, but preventive detention is allowed for national security.
examples: A detainee must be produced before a magistrate within 24 hours.
Preventive detention can last up to 3 months without advisory board approval.

article_title: Prohibition of traffic in human beings and forced labour
description: Traffic in human beings and begar and other similar forms of forced labour are prohibited.
simple_explanation: Slavery, human trafficking, and forced labour are banned.
examples: Bonded labour is illegal in India.
Trafficking women for prostitution violates Article 23.

article_title: Freedom of conscience and free profession, practice, and propagation of religion
description: All persons are equally entitled to freedom of conscience and the right to freely profess, practice, and propagate religion.
simple_explanation: Every individual can follow, change, and practice their religion freely.
examples: A Hindu can convert to Christianity or Islam by choice.
Religious processions are allowed but subject to public order.

description: Any section of the citizens having a distinct language, script, or culture of its own shall have the right to conserve the same.
simple_explanation: Minorities can protect their language, culture, and traditions.
examples: Kannada-speaking people in Maharashtra can open Kannada schools.
Tribal communities can preserve their unique customs.

article_title: Right of minorities to establish and administer educational institutions
description: All minorities, whether based on religion or language, shall have the right to establish and administer educational institutions of their choice.
simple_explanation: Minorities can set up their own schools and colleges.
examples: Christian minority institutions like St. Xavier’s College are protected under Article 30.
Muslim institutions like Aligarh Muslim University have constitutional protection.

article_title: Directive Principles of State Policy (economic justice)
description: The State shall direct its policy towards securing that men and women equally have the right to adequate means of livelihood, and resources are not concentrated in the hands of a few.
simple_explanation: Government should ensure fair distribution of wealth and equal livelihood opportunities.
examples: Reservation policies are linked with the spirit of Article 39.
Land reforms were based on this principle.

description: The State shall take steps to separate the judiciary from the executive in the public services of the State.
simple_explanation: Judges must be independent of government control.
examples: District Magistrates cannot interfere with judicial courts.
Judicial reforms are based on Article 50.

description: If the President is satisfied that the security of India is threatened by war, external aggression, or armed rebellion, a National Emergency may be proclaimed.
simple_explanation: A National Emergency gives extra powers to the Union Government.
examples: Indira Gandhi declared Emergency in 1975 under Article 352.
During Emergency, some Fundamental Rights can be suspended.

description: If the President is satisfied that the governance of a State cannot be carried on according to the Constitution, he may assume the functions of the State Government.
simple_explanation: If a State Government fails, the President can take over its functions.
examples: President’s Rule was imposed in Jammu & Kashmir multiple times.
If no party wins a majority in a State, President’s Rule can be declared.

article_title: Power of High Courts to issue writs
description: High Courts can issue writs for enforcement of Fundamental Rights and other purposes.
simple_explanation: High Courts also protect rights, not just the Supreme Court.
examples: A person can go to High Court for Habeas Corpus against unlawful detention.
High Courts can issue writs even for legal rights, not only Fundamental Rights.

description: Defines what constitutes a Money Bill, which can only be introduced in the Lok Sabha.
simple_explanation: Bills related to taxes and government money must start in Lok Sabha.
examples: GST-related bills are Money Bills.
Finance Bill is always a Money Bill.

description: The President shall cause to be laid before both Houses of Parliament the Annual Financial Statement.
simple_explanation: The government’s yearly budget is presented in Parliament.
examples: The Union Budget every year is mandated by Article 112.

article_title: Power of President to promulgate Ordinances
description: When Parliament is not in session, the President may issue ordinances having the force of law.
simple_explanation: President can make temporary laws when Parliament is not working.
examples: Banking Regulation Ordinance before passing in Parliament.
Indira Gandhi used ordinances frequently.

article_title: Special leave to appeal by the Supreme Court
description: The Supreme Court may grant special leave to appeal from any judgment, decree, determination, sentence or order.
simple_explanation: SC can allow appeals from lower courts in exceptional cases.
examples: Any citizen can approach SC if they feel injustice has occurred.
SC intervened in many landmark cases through Article 136.

article_title: Review of judgments or orders by the Supreme Court
description: The Supreme Court shall have power to review its own judgments or orders.
simple_explanation: SC can change its own judgment if needed.
examples: SC reviewed its Sabarimala temple entry judgment.
Review petitions are filed under Article 137.

article_title: Law declared by Supreme Court binding on all courts
description: The law declared by the Supreme Court shall be binding on all courts within India.
simple_explanation: Whatever SC decides, lower courts must follow.
examples: Kesavananda Bharati case (Basic Structure) binds all courts.
Right to Privacy judgment is binding.

article_title: Comptroller and Auditor General of India (CAG)
description: CAG is appointed to audit government accounts and ensure financial accountability.
simple_explanation: CAG checks if government spends money properly.
examples: CAG exposed the 2G spectrum scam.
CAG audits defence and railway accounts.

article_title: Powers, privileges and immunities of State Legislatures
description: State Legislatures enjoy certain privileges similar to Parliament to function independently.
simple_explanation: MLAs in State Assemblies enjoy certain immunities like MPs.
examples: Freedom of speech in State Assemblies.
Protection from court proceedings for statements inside Assembly.

description: The President shall constitute a Finance Commission every five years to recommend distribution of taxes between Union and States.
simple_explanation: A Finance Commission ensures fair distribution of money between Centre and States.
examples: 15th Finance Commission gave recommendations for 2021-26.
It decides how much GST share States get.

description: No person shall be deprived of his property except by authority of law.
simple_explanation: Property rights exist but are no longer fundamental.
examples: Government can acquire land only through legal process.
Compensation must be given for acquisition.

description: The Parliament may amend by way of addition, variation or repeal any provision of this Constitution.
simple_explanation: Parliament can change the Constitution through special procedures.
examples: 42nd Amendment added words 'Socialist' and 'Secular'.
101st Amendment introduced GST.

article_title: Temporary provisions with respect to the State of Jammu and Kashmir (abrogated in 2019)
description: Special status was granted to J&K under Article 370, later abrogated in August 2019.
simple_explanation: J&K had special autonomy, but now it is revoked.
examples: Before 2019, J&K had its own Constitution.
After abrogation, Indian laws apply directly.

description: Provides special provisions for states like Maharashtra, Gujarat, Nagaland, Assam, Manipur, Andhra Pradesh, etc.
simple_explanation: Some states have special safeguards for their culture, law, and governance.
examples: Nagaland has autonomy regarding its customary laws.
Maharashtra and Gujarat got provisions for separate development boards.
